subject: Normalize sorting
commit_message:
Normalize sorting

The idea behind this patch is to disable default sorting for inner
listing operation, because it's not requred there, and leave it
only for api calls.

With this patch we also remove two unnecessary auxiliary functions from
db api: _get_collection_sorted_by_time and _get_collection_sorted_by_name.
Currently they are used to specify default parameters for 'sort_keys',
but unfortunately they do it wrong, which leads to confusion and
incorrect behavior of the system, when _get_collection_sorted_by_name
is used to sort by time [1], when mutable is passed as a default
parameter value and then modified in the code[2][3] (this is one of the
most famous python anti-patterns [4]).

To cope with non-determinism in tests instead of assertEqual method we use
_assert_single_item, which allows to check results regardless of their
order.

Therefore, the patch allows to increase the performance of Mistral and make
the code cleaner.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/stable/pike/mistral/db/v2/sqlalchemy/api.py#L528-L539
[2] https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/stable/pike/mistral/db/v2/sqlalchemy/api.py#L235
[3] https://github.com/openstack/mistral/blob/stable/pike/mistral/db/v2/sqlalchemy/api.py#L183-L184
[4] https://docs.quantifiedcode.com/python-anti-patterns/correctness/mutable_default_value_as_argument.html

Change-Id: Ib4380f883969cab4ab851cd910c830e5ce30dfe5

subject: Fix adjusted_free_virtual in CapacityFilter
commit_message:
Fix adjusted_free_virtual in CapacityFilter

There are two ways to calculate adjusted_free_virtual
in CapacityFilter.

Take mosr as backend_state.max_over_subscription_ratio

adjusted_free_virtual1 = free * mosr
= (total - used - reserved*total)*mosr
= total(1-reserved)*mosr - used*mosr:
eg:  total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 0TB
     free = total - used - total*reserved = 1TB
     adjusted_free_virtual1 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 0 = 2TB
because of used = 0, when a lot of volume to be creating,
they all see 1TB adjusted_free_virtual.

adjusted_free_virtual2 = cinder.utils.calculate_virtual_free_capacity
= total*mosr - provisioned - reserved*mosr
= total(1-reserved)*mosr - provisioned:
eg:  total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 1TB
     free = total - free - total*reserved = 1TB - 1TB - 0= 0
     adjusted_free_virtual2 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 1TB = 1TB > 0 = free
but there are no space left on the pool or backend.

For provisioned > used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 > adjusted_free_virtual2.
For provisioned < used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 < adjusted_free_virtual2.
For provisioned = used*mosr,
    adjusted_free_virtual1 = adjusted_free_virtual2.

subject: Fix free_capacity
commit_message:
Fix free_capacity

There are two ways to calculate free_capacity.

Take mosr as backend_state.max_over_subscription_ratio

free_capacity1 = free * mosr
 = (total - used - reserved*total)*mosr
 = total(1-reserved)*mosr - used*mosr:
 eg: total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 0TB
     free = total - used - total*reserved = 1TB - 0 - 0 = 1TB
     free_capacity1 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 0 = 2TB
     because of used = 0, when a lot of volume to be creating,
     they all see 1TB free_capacity.

free_capacity2
 = cinder.utils.calculate_virtual_free_capacity
 = total*mosr - provisioned - reserved*mosr
 = total(1-reserved)*mosr - provisioned:
 eg: total = 1TB
     reserved = 0
     mosr = 2
     provisioned = 1TB
     used = 1TB
     free = total - free - total*reserved = 1TB - 1TB - 0= 0
     free_capacity2 = 1TB(1-0)*2 - 1TB = 1TB > 0 = free
     but there are no space left on the pool or backend.

For provisioned > used*mosr, free_capacity1 > free_capacity2.
For provisioned < used*mosr, free_capacity1 < free_capacity2.
For provisioned = used*mosr, free_capacity1 = free_capacity2.

free_capacity = min(free_capacity1, free_capacity2)
will solve above problems.

Change-Id: Id2f24872401b1a91ed6f37a2b7e234a676fc4d60
Closes-Bug: #1719756

subject: Test alloc candidates with same RC in cn & shared
commit_message:
Test alloc candidates with same RC in cn & shared

This change set adds a couple of failing test cases that demonstrate
holes in the design of GET /allocation_candidates when inventory from
the same resource class is present on both the compute node (the "main"
resource provider) and a shared resource provider.

The example being used is where the compute node has some local disk,
and is also associated with a shared storage pool.  Both the compute
node RP and the shared storage RP will provide inventory of DISK_GB.

Test case test_common_rc demonstrates bug #1724613: when I ask for
DISK_GB in this setup, the shared storage pool is ignored.  I expect to
get two candidates back: one with the storage from the compute node; the
other with the storage from the shared storage pool.  But I actually
only get the former candidate back.

Test case test_common_rc_traits_split shows bug #1724633: that placement
can't tell which traits are supposed to apply to which resources.  In
the above scenario, if the local storage is SSD and the shared storage
is RAID, and I ask for SSD + RAID, I "expect" to get back no hits.  But
I would in fact get back a candidate with the storage from the shared
storage pool, because the cumulative set of traits would satisfy my
requested SSD + RAID.

Note that the two tests are functionally identical (traits are ignored
entirely) until https://review.openstack.org/#/c/479766/ lands.  At that
point, depending on how we decide to implement the code that would deal
with this scenario, the test may fail *differently* until bug #1724613
is fixed.

subject: Fix tempest scenario tests waiters
commit_message:
Fix tempest scenario tests waiters

Cleanups for resources such as listeners, pools and health monitors are
currently using a waiter named _wait_for_load_balancer_status to get an
indication that the cleanup process ended successfully.

Because of the way that waiter is currently used in those cleanups,
it's basically just checking that the load balancer state is:
provisioning_status='ACTIVE'
operating_status='ONLINE'

This is not a good measure for the success of a cleanup for the
aforementioned resources since the deletion process of those simply has
no effect on either loadbalancer provisioning_status or
operating_status. Thus, this is not a good indicator.

This creates issues on high load test deployments.
For example: test_listener_basic is a scenario that deletes a listener
and verifies the absence of the load balancing functionality via
_check_load_balancing_after_deleting_resources.
In case the listener deletion is still undergoing (and currently it
does not have a good indication for that), the load balancer will
accept the traffic and fail the test.

The suggestion solution here is not to use _wait_for_load_balancer_status
as an indicator, but rather add waiters to check specifically if a given
resource got deleted or not.

Change-Id: Ib2e4c60e2db28f1345665c2f5859e8f5fde75bc0

subject: Add shared_targets and backend_id to volumes
commit_message:
Add shared_targets and backend_id to volumes

It would make life simpler for Nova and other consumers to know
if they're dealing with devices that utilize shared targets and
give them explicit information to enable things like device
(backend_id) locking.

This change adds two new columns to the Volume Table, shared_targets
and backend_id.

The shared_targets column is a boolean that indicates if the device
that hosts the volume utilizes shared_targets or not.  By default
we set this to True because it's safe to treat all volumes as shared
but not the other way around.

The backend_id column defaults to using the associated c-vol service
UUID.  This can be overridden via the config option "backend_id" for
cases where a cloud is deployed using a single backend device to
support multiple c-vol services (in the same cloud).

This change results in the following:
1. API Microversion bump (provides shared_targets and backend_id
   fields in the detailed volume view.
2. Object version bump to add respective fields to Volume Object
3. Addition of driver config option `backend_id`

Implements: blueprint add-shared-targets-flag-to-volume

most common state in the instance action notifications. This way

commit_message:
Fix instance lookup in hide_server_addresses extension

The hide_server_addresses extension is looking up the cached
instance based on what the user provided for the server id,
which may not match what is used to cache the instance for the
request. For example, a request with upper-case server uuid
could be found in a mysql-backed system because mysql is
case insensitive by default, but the instance is keyed off the
server id from the DB, which is lower-case, so we'll fail
to look up the instance in the cache if the IDs don't match.

There is no test for this because it turns out it's actually
really hard to recreate this since it requires running with a
mysql backend to recreate the case insensitive check, which
isn't going to work with sqlite. Given how trivial this fix is,
creating a big mysql recreate test is not worth it.

subject: Fix qemu image compatibility mode
commit_message:
Fix qemu image compatibility mode

The qemu compatibility mode preserves compatibility with the
previous generation of the qemu-img tools. In 2014, when Ubuntu
Trusty was introduced, it was set to compat=0.10 to provide
compatibility with servers installed with Ubuntu Precise as
both Trusty and Precise were supported at that time.

Precise is now End of Life since April 2017, so the compatibility
mode is being updated to the default mode that exists for Trusty
which is compat=1.1.  The mode has not been updated since then.

Updating the mode has the advantage of picking up support for
newer qemu features like more efficient copy-on-read behavior.
Setting it to an explicit value ensures that the mode is not
silently changed.

subject: Fix unstable test case
commit_message:
Fix unstable test case

The DatabaseConfigurationsTests.test_values_tab_discard_action
test is unstable, failing and succeeding on subsequent runs.

The root cause of the instability is the django local memory cache
used by the test cases. This cache has defaults that will cull
33% of the cache entries when it reaches its max capacity of 300.

During the test runs the cache becomes full and the culling will
randomly choose to cull the cached configuratoin being used by the
test case about 33% of the time. This leads to test case failure.

In a production environment the cache used is memcached which has
different behavior. If the cache entry were still culled, for the
"discard changes" option, that would be equivalent to a discard
since the configuration manager would re-fetch.

In the test case flow it breaks because the 'changed values'
fetch gets a cache miss.

The fix is to set the cache configuration for the tests to use
a higher max_entries value and change the cull frequency to only
cull 5% of the entries every cull.

Change-Id: I44bcf14c4ed17505de94b44b01ffcccd818399b7

subject: Avoid redundant security group queries in GET /servers/{id}/os-security-groups
commit_message:
Avoid redundant security group queries in GET /servers/{id}/os-security-groups

The GET /servers/{server_id}/os-security-groups API code can
perform poorly if the instance has several security groups and
each security group has several rules. This is because when processing
the output, we loop over the groups, and loop over the rules per group,
and then for each rule, if it has a group_id specified, we query
the security group details (from Neutron in most cases).

If more than one rule points at the same group_id, we're doing a redundant
group lookup and sending more traffic to the security group API (aka Neutron)
than needed.

This change optimizes that single API to load the rule group details
up front so that we only do at most one lookup per group_id.

This could be extended to GET /os-security-groups but that API is
deprecated so any optimization there is lower priority.

Change-Id: Ia451429f61b15526fade6838386e562c17591d36
Closes-Bug: #1729741

subject: Properly detect RBD in use on Cinder backends
commit_message:
Properly detect RBD in use on Cinder backends

The Cinder RBD in use host_var was not being set correctly when RBD
backends are defined in extra vars files. Instead we should use a
set_fact as implemented in Pike and master, instead of the current
broken implementation in Ocata.

A similar set fact is also added to the cinder playbook. This set
fact does not exist in Pike and master since cinder's glance API
version setting is no longer a ternary 1/2 switch, the setting is
removed since Cinder uses Glance v2 by default in Pike+. We add the
set fact here since Ocata still has a ternary switch to determine
which glance API version to use.
